id store(String key, Object val);
> >     Object retrieve(String key);
> > =
    void remove(String key);

> > That interface is enough to kno=
w how to use the object store.

> So what are your "solid enough" contrac=
ts? How do you find 
> those contracts by looking at nothing but an interfa=
ce definition?


I start there.  However, there are some questions that nee=
d to be
answered when looking at this specific interface.

What happens if =
I store an object with a key value that already
exists?  Is there an except=
ion to be thrown, or does it silently
overwrite the value there.

The inter=
face above suggests that the object is silently overwritten.
I would likely=
 change the contract of the interface to introduce the
exception.  I would =
also add javadocs to describe that contract in plain
english.

Next questio=
n is does the retrieve() method remove the object from the
store?  The exis=
tense of the the remove() method suggests that they
happen
separately.  The=
refore I add javadocs to clearly state that the
retrieve()
method does not =
remove the object from the store.

Lastly, we find that a useful method bot=
h for testing and dynamic key
selection would suggest  that we need a new m=
ethod to see if a key is
already used.  I would likely add that in.

You al=
ways have to have somewhere to start.  Usually when you design
such a compo=
nent, you already have a usecase in mind.  You test for that
usecase, and m=
ake sure that the contracts of that usecase are clearly
stated in the inter=
face.
